Field Label: Record ID

Welcome!

Many thanks for your interest in our study "Light exposure in daily life"! 

Before we invite you to our facility at the Georg-Brauchle-Ring, we would like to make sure that you are eligible for this study. Below, you will fill out some questionnaires about yourself and your health. In this screening we will also collect sensitive data according to the data protection law (Art.9 DS-26 GVO), especially health data. In addition, we will ask you for your e-mail address so that we can contact you.

What is the study about?

This study aims to describe the amount and type of light that individuals are exposed to in their daily life using a light logging sensor. We are interested in whether light exposure is associated with health-related variables, such as sleep, wellbeing, alertness, and light sensitivity. The total duration of the study is 1 week (from Monday to Monday). Participation in the study involves the following steps:

  1. This short screening questionnaire, which contains demographic and health questions. After finishing this questionnaire and if you are eligible, we will contact you to take part in this study via the e-mail address that we will ask you to provide. Together, we will agree on a date to start the experiment.

  2. On the Monday of the experimental week, you will come to our laboratory at Georg-Brauchle-Ring in the afternoon. Here, you will fill in two questionnaires about your chronotype and we will give you the light logging sensor. This consists of a small light sensor placed on the frame of a pair of black, non-prescription glasses (variable sizes are available). Furthermore, we will give you a light logger with a wristband and a necklace band.

  3. During the experimental week, you will wear all devices continuously and only take them off during showering or contact sports. During sleep, we will ask you to place the light logger somewhere in your room (e.g. bedside table). Furthermore, during the week, you will complete daily sleep, wellbeing, exercise, and light exposure diaries directly on your phone through an app.

  4. At the end of the week (i.e. the following Monday), you will come back to the lab in the morning and we will ask you to complete questionnaires about your light exposure and light sensitivity. We will also ask you about your experiences with wearing our light logging device. 

Will I get reimbursed?

You will receive compensation for participating in this study. For each day of wearing the light logger devices, you will receive €10. Please note that this daily compensation will only be applied if you wear the devices more than 80% of your awake time per day. This means that, if you comply with this criterion, we will give you a total of €80 on the final day of the study.

What happens with my data?

Sensitive data about you and your health will be collected in this study. This data will be treated confidentially. The legal basis for this is your declaration of consent (Art. 6 para. 1 lit. a, Art. 9 para 2 lit. a. DSGVO). The Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics is responsible for data processing. All data that can identify your person are pseudonymized by an identification code. The data is stored at the Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics and at the Technical University of Munich.

Before starting the online questionnaire, we ask for your consent:

1. I voluntarily agree to participate in the online survey for the study "Light exposure in daily life".

2. I know that my consent is voluntary and that I can withdraw it at any time without negative consequences for myself.

3. I agree with the collection, the processing and the analysis of my data by the Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics and the Technical University Munich.

4. Data may be collected by the Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics and the Technical University of Munich as part of scientific research to determine eligibility for further participation in the study.

Any more questions?

The full description of the study can be found in the document attached here. For any other doubts or questions, feel free to contact Suyoun (Suyoun.lee@tum.de) and Sarina (Sarina.hilden@tum.de)
